title: Grocery Store Delivery Service
content:
Your local grocery store offers home delivery for online orders. Each morning, trucks load up at the store (<loc_depot>) with bags of groceries (<demand>) for customers across the neighborhood (<loc_customer>).  
Each truck can only carry so much (<capacity>), and drivers finish their shift after the last delivery—no need to return to the store.  
The goal? Plan routes that:  
✓ Fit all orders without overloading any truck.  
✓ Minimize total driving distance to save fuel and time.  
✓ Let drivers end their day close to home.

title: Waste Collection for Recycling Centers
content:
Your city’s recycling trucks start their day at the depot (<loc_depot>) and visit scattered recycling bins (<loc_customer>) to collect paper, plastic, and glass.  
Each bin has a different weight (<demand>), and trucks have a strict weight limit (<capacity>).  
After emptying their last bin, drivers park at a nearby lot instead of driving back to the depot.  
The challenge: Design routes that:  
✓ Never exceed truck capacity.  
✓ Cover all bins in the fewest miles.  
✓ Let drivers finish near their next job.

title: Food Bank Distribution
content:
A charity delivers donated food from a central warehouse (<loc_depot>) to soup kitchens and shelters (<loc_customer>).  
Each location needs a different amount of food (<demand>), and vans can only carry so much (<capacity>).  
Drivers end their shift after the last drop-off to avoid empty return trips.  
The goal is to:  
✓ Deliver all food without overloading vans.  
✓ Use the shortest possible routes to serve more people faster.  
✓ Keep drivers from wasting time on unnecessary trips.

title: Mobile Vaccination Clinics
content:
During a health campaign, nurses travel from a hospital (<loc_depot>) to set up temporary vaccination sites (<loc_customer>).  
Each site requires a specific number of vaccine doses (<demand>), and each nurse’s cooler can only hold so many (<capacity>).  
After the last vaccination, nurses head home instead of returning to the hospital.  
The task: Plan routes that:  
✓ Distribute all doses without exceeding cooler limits.  
✓ Minimize travel time to reach more communities.  
✓ Let nurses finish near their homes.

title: Flower Delivery for Special Events
content:
A florist delivers bouquets from their shop (<loc_depot>) to wedding venues, restaurants, and homes (<loc_customer>) for events.  
Each order has a different size (<demand>), and delivery vans have limited space (<capacity>).  
Drivers finish their day after the last delivery—no need to go back to the shop.  
The challenge: Arrange routes that:  
✓ Fit all bouquets in one trip per van.  
✓ Reduce total driving distance to keep flowers fresh.  
✓ Let drivers end near their next job or home.

title: Coffee Truck Daily Stops
content:
Your mobile coffee truck starts each morning at the roastery (<loc_depot>) with a limited supply of beans, milk, and pastries (<capacity>).  
You’ve got regular stops (<loc_customer>)—office parks, construction sites—where each orders a different amount (<demand> cups + snacks).  
Once you sell out at the last stop, you’re done for the day (no need to drive back).  
The trick? Plan a route that:  
✓ Never runs out of supplies early.  
✓ Hits the busiest spots first when demand is high.  
✓ Minimizes driving so you spend less on gas and more time serving customers.

title: Moving Company Relocation Day
content:
Your moving company has one big truck (<capacity>) starting at the storage warehouse (<loc_depot>).  
Today, you need to deliver furniture to three families (<loc_customer>), each with a different load size (<demand> boxes/beds).  
After the last drop-off, the crew clocks out (no return trip).  
Optimize the route so:  
• The truck isn’t overloaded.  
• Heavy items go first to balance weight.  
• Total miles are minimized—saving time and diesel.

title: Farm-to-Table Produce Run
content:
A small farm (<loc_depot>) packs its harvest into a van (<capacity> crates) to deliver to restaurants (<loc_customer>) that ordered varying amounts (<demand>).  
Since produce spoils fast, the van must visit all spots in one go, and the driver can head home after the last drop.  
Goal: Arrange stops so:  
✓ No crate is left undelivered.  
✓ The shortest route keeps veggies fresh.  
✓ The van’s capacity isn’t exceeded (those watermelons are heavy!).

title: City Park Maintenance Crew
content:

After the final park, the team leaves the truck there overnight.  
Plan routes where:

• No truck is overloaded with heavy soil bags.

title: Festival Merchandise Delivery
content:

✓ Avoid congested areas during peak hours.  
✓ Keep the van’s load under capacity (those poster tubes take up space!).

content:

Each stop requires different supplies (<demand>) based on registered pets. After the final clinic, vans park at that location for overnight storage. Plan routes that:

✓ Let staff end their day at the last clinic

Design routes that:
